Tip: Log in 2-3 minutes early to avoid system lag delays
Set phone reminders 5 minutes before breaks end
Keep a visible timer on your desk for break times
Take 10 extra seconds to confirm you fully answered the question before ending call
Ask 'Is there anything else I can help you with today?' and wait for response
Use teach-back method: 'Let me make sure I explained that clearly...' to catch confusion
Before transferring, take 10 seconds to check knowledge base - customers prefer waiting over restarting
Say 'Let me see if I can help you with that first' before defaulting to transfer
Memorize which department handles top 5 transfer reasons to route correctly first time
Use quick reference card while talking - it's faster than searching knowledge base mid-call
Memorize top 5 most common customer questions to avoid looking up every time
Practice your greeting and closing to get under 10 seconds each
Put customer on hold BEFORE looking things up, not after. Say 'Let me pull that up, one moment' then hit hold button
Keep frequently used screens already open in browser tabs
Learn keyboard shortcuts for your main tools - mouse clicking adds 5-10 seconds per call
Start documentation DURING the call, not after - fill in account notes while talking
Use text expander shortcuts for common phrases like 'Customer called regarding billing question'
Have your wrap-up template ready to go - fill in blanks rather than typing from scratch
Smile while talking - customers hear it in your voice even on the phone
Use customer's name at least twice during call - beginning and end
Match the customer's energy level - if they're calm, be calm; if concerned, show empathy
Replace 'problem' with 'situation' - it sounds less negative
Say 'I'd be happy to help you with that' instead of 'I can help you'
Use 'absolutely' instead of 'yes' - it's more enthusiastic
Replace 'unfortunately' with 'what I can do is...' to focus on solutions
Never say 'I don't know' - say 'Great question, let me find that answer for you'
Avoid 'but' - use 'and' or 'however' to sound less contradictory
Take a 3-second breath before responding to frustrated customers
Use phrases like 'I understand your frustration' before solving - validate first
Lower your voice volume slightly when customer raises theirs - it naturally de-escalates
Set two alarms for your shift - one for wake up, one for leave house time
Have a backup plan for transportation issues - know your bus backup route
If you're running late, call supervisor as soon as you know - not when you arrive
Listen for the REAL issue behind the question - sometimes billing question is actually payment plan need
End every call with specific next steps - don't leave customer wondering what happens next
Follow up on promises - if you said you'd call back, call back
